thread.title: EDITORIAL: Old Inland Empire, new economic tricks
thread.title_full: EDITORIAL: Old Inland Empire, new economic tricks - Press Enterprise

author: The Press-Enterprise
title: EDITORIAL: Old Inland Empire, new economic tricks
text:
PRESS-ENTERPRISE EDITORIAL
Published: Oct. 2, 2015 Updated: 5:39 p.m. “Quite positive.”� That, to put it succinctly, is the economic forecast for the Inland Southern California region over the next several years, according to the UC Riverside School of Business Administration’s newly formed Center for Economic Forecasting and Development.
“The place we call home,” says Yunzeng Wang, dean of UCR’s business school, “packs a very significant economic punch not only here, but across the state and beyond.”
Mr. Wang’s statement might have suggested to some that he was suffering from what former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan famously termed “irrational exuberance.”
But the dean’s statement was backed up by data presented by respected economist Chris Thornberg, the center’s recently-named director, and his colleague Jordan Levine, the center’s director of research.
According to Dr. Levine, Inland Southern California is the 24th largest economy among the nation’s top 50 metropolitan areas, with output of $134 billion. If the region were a state, it would rank 33rd in GDP – just ahead of Nevada.
Inland Southern California’s robust economic expansion is attributable in no small part to taxable sales growth that surpasses Los Angeles and Orange counties. Indeed, the region saw a 5.4 percent increase in taxable sales during the first quarter of 2015, compared to 3.3 percent for L.A. County and 1.1 percent for Orange County.
And Dr. Levine and his colleagues at the Center for Economic Forecasting and Development foresee continued growth in taxable sales for Inland Southern California, forecasting an average rate of 6.5 percent over the next five years.
The region’s jobs picture is similarly promising, with non-farm employment reaching an all-time high this past July, and the unemployment rate declining to 6.4 percent. While joblessness remains 0.2 percent above the statewide rate, that is a considerable improvement over the 2 percent differential in December 2009.
And what bears watching is the evolution of Inland Southern California’s job market.
Indeed, the transportation and warehouse sector, “a bread-and-butter industry for the region,” the center reaffirmed, continues to add new positions to company payrolls – growing a robust 9.8 percent from July 2014 to July 2015.
But following closely was the professional, scientific and technical services sector, which grew its labor force by an impressive 9.4 percent for the year ending this past July.
Such jobs, which include legal services, accounting, architecture, engineering, computer systems design, scientific research and development and other high-skill, high-wage occupations, generally are not associated with Inland Southern California by those unfamiliar with the region.
But that’s old think about a region that, as Dr. Levine said, “has gotten a bad rap.” One that no longer is the sick man of California, but “a growth engine for the entire state.”
WRITE A LETTER TO THE EDITOR: Letters to the Editor: E-mail to letters@pe.com . Please provide your name, city and telephone number (telephone numbers will not be published). Letters of about 200 words will be given preference. Letters will be edited for length, grammar and clarity.
